newsitem.title: BURKINA FASO: Franco-African summit to send mission to Bangui.
newsitem.headline: Franco-African summit to send mission to Bangui.

text.p: The Franco-African summit in Burkina Faso decided on Thursday to send a mission to Central African Republic where an army mutiny is degenerating into ethnic conflict, an official statement said.

The statement from the office of host President Blaise Compaore said members of the "friendly mission" -- himself and the heads of state of Chad and Gabon -- would leave for Bangui in the next few days. It gave no other details.
The two-week-old mutiny forced Central African President Ange-Felix Patasse to miss the summit. His spokesman said on Tuesday he expected the meeting to send an assessment mission.

Before the summit opened on Thursday, French troops fought gunbattles with local army mutineers in Bangui but France said they acted in self-defence and would not be embroiled in the worsening conflict. France has a garrison in Bangui under defence accords.

Chirac's address to the gathering of about 30 heads of state, most of them of former French colonies, stressed the need for good governance and democracy as conditions for donor aid to Africa. Chirac and Compaore are scheduled to give a full news briefing on the summit when it ends early on Friday.
